options.label: B
options.text: It stores its poison in two separate chambers.

options.label: C
options.text: It has a specialized protein that binds and inactivates venom components in its blood.

options.label: D
options.text: It accumulates bitter-tasting compounds called alkaloids from consuming small arthropods.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They have accumulated bitter-tasting compounds called alkaloids from consuming small arthropods.

options.label: C
options.text: They have manufactured special proteins that bind and inactivate venom components in their blood.

options.label: D
options.text: They have packaged their venom safely in harpoon-like structures called nematocysts.

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in resistance and an increase in toxicity.

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in resistance and a decrease in toxicity.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They have packaged their venom safely in harpoon-like structures called nematocysts.

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: How much of what you see is a hallucination? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: What is Charles Bonnet Syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition where patients with schizophrenia hallucinate music or voices.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition where patients with impaired or total blindness suddenly hallucinate whole scenes in vivid color.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition where patients with hearing loss hallucinate music or voices.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition where patients with epilepsy hallucinate music or voices.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main cause of Charles Bonnet Syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: The brain's attempt to compensate for the lack of new visual input.

options.label: A
options.text: To activate the same brain areas as sight.

options.label: B
options.text: To process information from each of our senses.

options.label: C
options.text: To fill in blind spots with information from the surrounding area.

options.label: D
options.text: To block the same serotonin receptors LSD and psilocybin bind to.

options.label: B

options.label: A
options.text: To activate the same serotonin receptors as antipsychotic drugs.

options.label: B
options.text: To bind directly to one type of serotonin receptor.

options.label: C
options.text: To disrupt the signaling involved in sensory integration.

options.label: D
options.text: To block the same serotonin receptors as antipsychotic drugs.

options.label: A
options.text: Disrupting the signaling involved in sensory integration.

options.label: B
options.text: Blocking the same serotonin receptors as antipsychotic drugs.

options.label: C
options.text: Activating the same brain areas as sight.

options.label: D
options.text: Filling in blind spots with information from the surrounding area.

options.label: A
options.text: How our brains construct the world we see, hear, smell, and touch.

options.label: B
options.text: How our brains process information from each of our senses.

options.label: C
options.text: How our brains fill in blind spots with information from the surrounding area.

options.label: D
options.text: How our brains block the same serotonin receptors as antipsychotic drugs.
